tossups.question: A local history of these people titled This Happy Land recounts them settling “Ninety-Six” and profiles a planter who created a pokeberry brew to cure yaws and became Inspector-General of Indigo. After Thomas Jefferson’s death, a family of these people preserved Monticello. These people, who settled Texas in the Galveston movement, founded KKBE in Charleston. Earl Van Dorn’s raid on Holly Springs protected these people from (*) General Order No. 11, which Ulysses S. Grant issued to expel them over cotton speculation. The first of these people to hold a cabinet position was Jefferson Davis’s final Secretary of State. In The Secret Relationship, these people were falsely blamed for the slave trade by the Nation of Islam. For 10 points, what minority group included Judah P. Benjamin?
tossups.answer: Jewish Americans [or Jews; accept Sephardim or Sephardic Jews or Yahadut Sefarad; accept Ashkenazim or Ashkenazi Jews or Yehudei Ashkenaz; accept specific nationalities, like Russian Jews; accept The Secret Relationship Between Blacks and Jews; prompt on non-Christians or equivalents; prompt on Spanish or españoles or Portuguese or portugueses; prompt on British or English] (The indigo merchant was Moses Lindo. The Levy family purchased Monticello. KKBE is Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim.)

tossups.question: In a 2010 paper on the “Green” form of this framework, Brock and Taylor discuss its close connection to an environmental U-shaped curve. When one of the key variables from this framework is endogenized using theory developed by Frank Ramsey, the steady state can be reached by traveling along a “saddle path.” This framework superseded one that distinguished between warranted, actual, and natural types of a phenomenon and was developed by (*) Harrod and Domar. This framework posits the existence of a “golden rule” level of savings under its Cobb–Douglas production function. Under this framework, increases in per-capita income stem from exogenous technical change. For 10 points, name this benchmark model of economic growth that is sometimes co-named for Trevor Swan.
tossups.answer: Solow–Swan model [prompt on exogenous growth model until “exogenous”]

tossups.question: A piece composed for one of these events sets an earlier Henry Purcell text and begins with the main voice line being traded between soloists and the entire choir. An incomplete left-hand solo piano part in a concerto nicknamed for one of these events was likely completed by Johann André. Long melismas on the word “salvation” are included in a piece composed for one of these events, which name both a mass and a piano concerto by (*) Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. A long sequence of quiet violin arpeggios begins a piece composed for these events, whose 3/4-time middle section continuously repeats the word “rejoice.” Zadok the Priest is often played at––for 10 points––what ceremonies, one of which supposedly inspired George Handel to write the Water Music for his employer, George I?
tossups.answer: coronations [accept the coronation of a specific country’s monarch, such as the coronation of the British monarch; accept coronation anthems; accept Coronation Mass or Krönungsmesse; accept “Coronation” Concerto]

tossups.question: A perspective denoted by this word is represented by the bottom line of a diagram called “Coleman’s bathtub” or “boat.” Mary Rowe’s theory of this type of “inequity” is often discussed alongside a term beginning with this prefix that the psychologist Derald Wing Sue popularized. A “level of analysis” denoted  by this prefix is combined with a broader perspective in Anthony Giddens’s structuration theory, and focuses on how (*) agents behave within structure. This prefix comes before “assaults,” “insults,” and “invalidations” in terms used to describe interactions that express prejudice against marginalized groups in Chester Pierce’s theory of this sort of “aggression.” For 10 points, name this prefix that denotes small-scale approaches in the social sciences, in contrast to the “macro.”
tossups.answer: micro- [accept action or agency until “inequity” is read; accept microaggressions, microinvalidations, microinsults, or microassaults; accept micro-inequity]

tossups.question: Only Caspar Hare’s experiences have this property according to Caspar Hare’s “egocentric” analog of a theory named for this property, which itself faces the “truthmaker objection.” Rival models hold that states with this property are lit by a “moving spotlight,” or occupy one surface of a “growing block.” Martin Heidegger claimed that a “metaphysics” of this concept dominates Western thought, and distinguished between being (*) “ready-at-hand” and having this property “at hand.” This state is the second of three in the “Aseries” defined by J.M.E. McTaggart. This adjective and “bald” describe a “king of France” in a sentence analyzed in Bertrand Russell’s “On Denoting.” For 10 points, the grammatical tense of “I
tossups.answer: being present [or presence; accept being in the present or presentism; accept “being here and now” until “here” is read; accept present-at-hand, presence-at-hand, vorhanden, or Vorhandenheit; prompt on existence]

bonuses.leadin: With time, the designs of these objects progressed from geometric to figurative, often literally depicting common idioms. For 10 points each;
answers: Akan weights [or mrammou; or abramo; accept, but DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL, goldweights]
gold dust [or Au; prompt on precious metals]
Maxim gun [prompt on machine guns]
parts: Name these brass objects, crucial to the work of adwumfos until the end of the 19th century. These objects were frequently used in conjunction with brass spoons and elaborate boxes called kuduo.

The Akan people used mrammou to measure out this substance that fueled the economy of the Asante Empire and many other West African states. Mansa Musa devalued this substance by distributing so much of it on his hajj.

This new weapon partially enabled a British victory over the Asante that led to the obsolescence of Akan goldweights when the pound became the local currency. This first automatic firearm was heavily utilized by European colonial powers during the Scramble for Africa.

bonuses.leadin: The British occupied an outpost in Omoa built by enslaved Africans for this country’s forces, who campaigned against Baymen at the British settlements of Black River and Saint George's Caye. For 10 points each:
answers: Spain [or the Spanish; or Kingdom of Spain or Reino de España]
1780 [accept Great Hurricane of 1780 or 1780 disaster]
Baja California [accept Baja California Sur or Baja California Norte; prompt on California]
parts: Name this American ally that fought the British at the battles of St. Louis and Arkansas Post. The naval officer George Farragut was born in this modern-day country, whose forces briefly captured New Providence.

In this year, the worst ever Atlantic hurricane delayed Spain’s siege of Pensacola to the next year. In this year, Horatio Nelson led the San Juan expedition to Nicaragua, Spain lost the moonlit Battle of Cape St. Vincent over Gibraltar, and the Fourth Anglo-Dutch War began.

In 1780, the Dominican priest Miguel Hidalgo founded Misión San Vicente Ferrer on this peninsula to convert Yuman peoples like the Paipai. The Spanish settled Loreto on this peninsula located south of its “alta” counterpart.

bonuses.leadin: This practice was marked with “passages,” “portals,” and megalithic dolmens at many Neolithic sites in Scotland and Ireland, such as Poulnabrone and Newgrange. For 10 points each:
answers: burial [or interment or inhumation or entombment; accept funerary practices or equivalents; accept grave goods or passage graves; accept secondary burial or double burial; accept cemetery; accept megalithic tombs or portal tombs; accept burial mounds]
Mehrgarh
embalming [accept mummification or making a mummy; prompt on desiccation or drying out; prompt on preservation or similar]
parts: Name this practice that is considered “secondary” if its subject is manipulated twice. At many Neolithic sites, such as China’s Bànpō village, this practice was accompanied with food offerings or namesake “goods.”

Open spaces between houses were used for burial during Period I at this key Neolithic site in Balochistan. The Indus Valley culture may derive from this pre-Harappan site settled by early barley and wheat farmers.

The Period I grave goods at Mehrgarh included baskets lined with bitumen, which was later used with natron for this process in New Kingdom Egypt. During this process, the organs were placed in canopic jars.

bonuses.leadin: Anna Tsing included the caption “this diagram is both serious and a joke” on an illustration of the “spectacular” type of this process. For 10 points each:
answers: accumulation [accept spectacular accumulation or primitive accumulation]
Indonesia [or Republic of Indonesia or Republik Indonesia]
Europe [accept Europe and the People Without History; prompt on Eurasia]
parts: Name this process of increasing capital through the expropriation of surplus value. Marx held that capitalism developed through the “primitive” form of this process.

Tsing discussed “spectacular accumulation” in Friction, a book about “zones of awkward engagement” among miners and loggers in this country. Tsing’s In the Realm of the Diamond Queen also focuses on this country.

Eric Wolf studied how accumulation affects “people without history” in a book titled for this continent. Wolf coined the term “the great dying” for the global effects of colonial powers originating on this continent.

bonuses.leadin: In Erica Brenner’s reading, mentions of this concept function as a code to indicate actions lacking in virtù. For 10 points each:
answers: fortune [or fortuna; prompt on synonyms like luck, chance, or fate]
Niccolò Machiavelli [or Niccolò di Bernardo dei Machiavelli or Nicholas Machiavel]
prophets [or profeta or profeti; or visionaries; prompt on priests, preachers, or friars] (That contemporary was Girolamo Savonarola.)
parts: Name this concept that is compared to a raging river and to a woman that must be “mastered” in a treatise dedicated to Lorenzo de Medici.
Hanna Pitkin’s Fortune is a Woman examines gender in the work of this Italian author of The Prince.

In discussing the priority of virtù over fortuna, Machiavelli notes that these people must be “armed” to succeed. As an example of an “unarmed” one of these people, he uses a contemporary of his who also influenced Pico della Mirandola.

bonuses.leadin: Black composers have often synthesized African American and European musical traditions. For 10 points each:
answers: Mississippi River [accept Mississippi Delta; accept Mississippi River Suite]
William Grant Still
Scott Joplin
parts: Florence Price depicted this river in a “Suite” that quotes numerous folk songs popular among some inhabitants of this river’s Delta region, including “Go Down Moses” and “Deep River.”
After conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra in 1936, this composer of the Afro-American Symphony became the first Black musician to conduct a major American orchestra.

Interest in this composer was revived in the 1970s by musicologist Joshua Rifkin, which contributed to this composer’s posthumous Pulitzer Prize in 1976 for his folk- and jazz-influenced opera Treemonisha.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about how the 93rd Academy Awards broke tradition by presenting the Best Actor award last instead of the Best Picture award, for 10 points each.
answers: Chadwick Boseman [or Chadwick Aaron Boseman]
The Father
Youn Yuh-jung
parts: Many people speculated that the change occurred because the producers expected this late actor to win for his performance as Levee Green in Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom. He also played T’Challa in Black Panther.
The Best Actor award instead went to Anthony Hopkins for his role in this film, the directorial debut of the French playwright Florian Zeller.

While Steven Yeun, who was nominated for the Best Actor award for Minari, did not win the award, this costar of Yeun won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress. In doing so, she became the first Korean woman to win the award.
